instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green Light
threads.message: Board has no green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is present on <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> while <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is low 0.4v at <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>. Any ideas ?

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green Light
threads.message:
Check First 

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> 
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>

Then have you got around 4v on acin ? (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>)

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green Light
threads.message: You already gave the answer, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is low it should be high.

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green Light
threads.message:
_L means signal is present when low.

SMC RESET being 0.4v means SMC RESET is present.

hold down the reset button to a traditional old desktop computer. does it work? 

the SMC won't work until the reset signal is no longer present. since _L means it is present when it is low, it has to be high. 

so what chip is responsible for <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>? :)

threads.title: [solved]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green Light
threads.message: Solved. Board repaired, replaced <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> from donor board. Thanks guys
